First of all, thanx a lot to all of you guys(Sachin, Keith, Selena)

Selena, your link certainly got me started(To be true, i am not yet thru
with it, it seems to be a good starting point).
Sachin, your steps have creatinly cleared my doubts
and Keith i am sorry to use 'structure' where i should have used 'package'
(seems like I am not yet over with hangover of C, :-)   ),  CodeWarrior Java
seems to be a fine IDE. I am using Kawa3.5 which again i think is a good
tool. Your explaination have certainly cleared my doubts. But i still need
help from all you guys.

There can be two things when we start testing
[1] The code already exists, and now i have to write testcases for it.
[2] Starting with test first design

Now if i consider [1], should i make an exact replica of the existing class,
and start testing all its methods. This seems to be a dumb question, but is
there any link between the code(java/classfile) which forms the part of
application and the testfile.
I mean( which actually i dont think is correct) can a class be a part of
testclass. So this gives rise to 2 of my queries

a) Say if i have ClassA and ClassATest, does ClassATest ever extends of uses
object of ClassA?
b) Do i ever fiddle with the data members of ClassA.java like making a few
members from private to public so that the ClassATest.java may be able to
access them? This seems to only be a correct question if (a) is correct.

Now considering [2], if i start with testing first, now say i write a
ClassATest.java , so once this is working fine, my next step should be to
actually write ClassA.java. Is it Correct?

Please do clear my naive queries.

Thanx and Regards,
Manpreet

  -----Original Message-----
  From: Keith Ray [mailto:keith.ray@...]
  Sent: Monday, March 19, 2001 11:22 PM
  To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
  Subject: [junit] RE: How to write testcases?


  >My basic question is, Does writing testcases invlove making a different
  >structure all together, i mean writing classes and then testing them
  >independently from the code which is a part of my application.

  Using the word "structure" is confusing.  Do you mean "package"?

  Your java files can be in two packages/directories, or one, depending on
  your Java IDE...

  so you can do:

  com
      nowhere
          ClassOne.java
          ClassTwo.java
          ClassThree.java
  com
      nowhereTests
          ClassOneTest.java
          ClassTwoTest.java
          ClassThreeTest.java

  or you can do:

  com
       nowhere
           ClassOne.java
           ClassOneTest.java
           ClassTwo.java
           ClassTwoTest.java
           ClassThree.java
           ClassThreeTest.java

  With CodeWarrior Java for windows, I have a project with two targets. The
  'test' target has TestRunner or a class that calls TestRunner.main as the
  "main" class. The 'notest' target has my application's main class as the
  "main" class.

  file                               test target     notest target
  com.nowhere.ClassOne.java              x              x
  com.nowhere.ClassOneTest.java          x
  com.nowhere.ClassTwo.java              x              x
  com.nowhere.ClassTwoTest.java          x
  com.nowhere.ClassThree.java            x              x
  com.nowhere.ClassThreeTest.java        x
  com.nowhere.MainClass                                 x
  junit.swing.TestRunner                 x
  etc....

  When I build a jar file for release, CodeWarrior only puts classes that
are
  in the notest target into the jar file.
